doc.field: Extensive stop to deportation of Kosovo Albanians

Most of the federal states do not want to deport Albanians from the troubled Serbian province of Kosovo. Especially the SPD-ruled states want to wait and see how the situation develops in Kosovo. They went along with the decision of North-Rhine Westphalia and Lower Saxony to defer deportations until the end of this week. Bavaria and Baden-Wuerttemberg stressed, however, that they intended to continue with deportation on a case-by-case basis, without directly returning people to Kosovo. The Federal Interior Minister, Kanther, also spoke against a general stop to deportation, saying that the situation in Kosovo was difficult, but that he had no information to suggest that people who had been refused asylum had been subjected to human rights abuse in Yugoslavia.
Swear in of recruits in Berlin brought forward to 10 June

The controversial swearing in ceremony of Federal Army recruits in front of the Berlin City Hall, which was originally planned for 13 August, has been brought forward to 10 June. The change was agreed by Federal Defence Minister Ruehe and the city mayor, Diepgen. There was strong criticism from the SPD, the Greens and the PDS of the planned public taking of vows of recruits being held on 13 August, the anniversary of the building of the Berlin Wall in 1961.
FDP leader Gerhardt: FDP is and will remain loyal to coalition

The FDP leader, Gerhardt, has repeated his assertion that his party will remain loyal to the coalition. On the parliamentary vote on citizenship law, Gerhardt said the CDU/CSU should refrain from further warnings on the subject. Gerhardt stressed that the majority of the coalition is for the citizenship law. At the same time he said there is no such thing as "commando business" in the area of politics.
"Genetic fingerprinting" of sex offenders?

In future, sex offenders may have the genetic data of their saliva, sperm or hair logged in a central database, according to the Federal Interior Ministry. Re-offenders could then be identified more swiftly with the help of these genetic fingerprints. Federal Interior Minister, Manfred Kanther, and Federal Justice Minister Schmidt-Jortzig have agreed on a corresponding draft law. The data would be held for up to 20 years.
Turkish Foreign Minister cancels visit to Germany

The strained relationship between Germany and Turkey has worsened further. The Turkish Foreign Minster Cagar (Sp?) called off his planned visit to Germany today. The reason given was that the long-planned meeting with Federal Labour Minister Bluem had been reduced at the last minute to a lunch. It would not therefore be worth it for Cagar to travel to Germany. The Labour Ministry in Bonn rejected the complaint: it had been mutually agreed that an intensive discussion would follow the lunch. German-Turkish relations had already been strained following Nazi accusations made by the Turkish Minister President Yilmaz last week.
Federal President Herzog in South Africa

Federal President Herzog has praised the peaceful transition from the apartheid system to democratic society in South Africa. In a speech before the South African parliament in Cape Town, Herzog said that the change had been created through idealism and reason, giving Herzog hope for political development throughout the world. Herzog was received by South African President Nelson Mandela. Seven agreements were signed by both presidents, including a cultural agreement, and investment protection and an environmental agreement.
Girls at disadvantage when looking for training jobs

The German Federation of Union (DGB) has criticized that young women are disfavoured when looking for trainee jobs. Mr. Goerner, member of the DGB executive said girls were more strongly affected by the reduction of trainee jobs than boys. More than half of those who were still looking for a trainee job in January were female although only 49% of all applicants were women. Goerner assumes that the situation will become more serious because this year was the first time that more girls than boys were looking for a trainee job.
Telecommunications authority limits Telekom prices for phone lines

Private phone companies need not pay more than 20.65 DM per month to German Telekom [the former government-owned phone company] for renting a customer phone line. The regulatory authority for telecommunications and postal services decided that German Telekom did not provide sufficient evidence to support their calculations. German Telekom had demanded 28.80 DM per month.
Partial victory for Germany in "banana dispute"

Germany has achieved an important victory in the European Supreme Court regarding the European "banana dispute". The court nullified the EU's approval of a basic treaty with four Central American countries that export bananas. The treaty had put the traditional exporters and thus most of the German importers at a disadvantage. The import of Latin American bananas had been limited and a duty was imposed to promote the sale of bananas from Europe, Africa, and the Caribbean.
New trade fair in Stuttgart: generous offer to Leinfelden-Echterdingen

The State of Baden-Wuerttemberg has offered the City of Leinfelden-Echterdingen a number of compensatory measures in the dispute about the new location near the Stuttgart airport for the trade fair. Last night at a summit talk in the government building, State Premier Erwin Teufel proposed a 35-million-DM fund for the city if it agrees to the project. The money is intended for upgrading the city with, e.g., noise reduction implementations. Participants also reported that the city was offered to participate in the planning for the fairgrounds.
Tax frauds arrested in Stuttgart

Police and customs have apprehended five persons in the Stuttgart/ Ludwigsburg area who allegedly tricked 1.35 million DM from the tax office. The state criminal police arrested two men and one woman. All five confessed most allegations. Apparently, the group of five had registered several companies with the trade office since July last year. These companies issued each other fake bills. The head of the group then applied for and received a tax return. Money was transferred several times among various accounts as a cover-up. Several banks suspected money laundering and contacted the police.
